questionContent.questionText:
1. -pepsia [digestion]

2. -ptysis [spitting]

3. -emesis [vomiting]

4. -phagia [eating/swallowing]

5. -rrhea [flow/discharge]

6. -rrhage, -rrhagia [bursting forth of blood]

7. -rrhaphy [suture]

8. -plasty [surgical repair]

9. -ectasis, -ectasia [dilation/widening]

10. -stenosis [narrowing/tightening]

11. -stasis [to stop/control/to control]

12. -spasm [sudden contraction of muscles/involuntary contraction of muscles/sudden, involuntary contraction of muscles]

13. -tresia [opening]

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following suffixes.

readingPart.reading:
chol/egastr/oherni/o
cholangi/ohemat/opalat/o
choledoch/ohem/opylor/o

questionContent.questionText:
1. stoppage of bile (flow) [cholestasis]

2. suture of a hernia [herniorrhaphy]

3. dilation of bile ducts [cholangiectasia]

4. spitting up blood (from the respiratory tract) [hemoptysis]

5. vomiting blood (from the digestive tract) [hematemesis]

6. surgical repair of roof of the mouth [palatoplasty]

7. narrowing of the pyloric sphincter [pyloric stenosis]

8. bursting forth of blood from the stomach [gastrorrhagia]

9. sudden, involuntary contraction of muscles at the distal region of the stomach [pylorospasm]

10. bursting forth of blood [hemorrhage]

11. incision of the common bile duct [choledochotomy]

instructions.instructions: Build medical terms for the definitions that follow. Use the listed combining forms as appropriate to create terms.

readingPart.reading: esophagus is not open (closed off) at birth (congenital anomaly)
bursting forth of blood (hemorrhage) from the spleen
visual (endoscopic) examination of the rectum and sigmoid colon

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following terms.

readingPart.reading:
abdominoplastycolectomypalatoplasty
cecostomygingivectomypancreatoduodenectomy
cholecystectomyherniorrhaphyparacentesis
cholecystojejunostomyileostomysphincterotomy

questionContent.questionText:
1. removal of the gallbladder [cholecystectomy]

2. large bowel resection [colectomy]

3. suture of a weakened muscular wall (hernia) [herniorrhaphy]

4. new opening of the first part of the colon to the outside of the body [cecostomy]

5. surgical repair of the abdomen [abdominoplasty]

6. incision of a ring of muscles [sphincterotomy]

7. removal of the pancreas and duodenum [pancreatoduodenectomy]

8. opening of the third part of the small intestine to the outside of the body [ileostomy]

9. removal of gum tissue [gingivectomy]

10. anastomosis between the gallbladder and second part of the small intestine [cholecystojejunostomy]

11. puncture of the abdomen for withdrawal of fluid [paracentesis (abdominocentesis)]

12. surgical repair of the roof of the mouth [palatoplasty]

instructions.instructions: Match the listed surgical procedures with the meanings that follow.

questionContent.questionText:
1. discharge of fat: steat[orrhea]

2. difficulty in swallowing: dys[phagia]

3. abnormal condition of gallstones: chole[lithiasis]

4. pertaining to the cheek: [bucc]al

5. pertaining to lips and teeth: [labio]dental

6. vomiting blood: hemat[emesis]

7. enlargement of the liver: hepato[megaly]

8. pertaining to under the tongue: sub[lingual]

9. removal of the gallbladder:  [cholecyst]ectomy

10. pertaining to the common bile duct: chole[dochal]

11. hemorrhage from the stomach: gastro[rrhagia]

instructions.instructions: Use the given meanings to complete the following terms.

readingPart.reading: twisted intestine in the area of the cecum
inflammation of the mouth with small ulcers
autoimmune disorder in which villi in the lining of the small intestine are damaged, resulting from reaction to dietary glutens such as wheat, barley, and rye
the part of the throat near the mouth
removal of part or all of the tongue

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following terms.

readingPart.reading:
abdominal ultrasonographylaparoscopy
barium enemaliver biopsy
CT scan of the abdomennasogastric intubation
endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatographypercutaneous transhepatic cholangiography
endoscopic ultrasonographyserum bilirubin
bariatric surgery/gastric bypasssmall bowel follow-through
gastrostomy (G tube)stool culture
HIDA scanstool guaiac (Hemoccult)

questionContent.questionText:
1. measurement of bile pigment in the blood [serum bilirubin]

2. placement of feces in a growth medium for bacterial analysis [stool culture]

3. x-ray examination of the lower gastrointestinal tract [barium enema]

4. imaging of abdominal viscera using sound waves [abdominal ultrasonography]

5. test to reveal hidden blood in feces
[stool guaiac (Hemoccult)]

6. sequential x-ray images of the small intestine [small bowel follow-through]

7. injection of contrast material through the skin into the liver, to obtain x-ray images of bile vessels [percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTHC)]

8. insertion of a tube through the nose into the stomach [nasogastric intubation]

9. transverse x-ray pictures of the abdominal organs [CT scan of the abdomen]

10. injection of contrast material through an endoscope for x-ray imaging of the pancreas and bile ducts [endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)]

11. reduction of stomach size and gastrojejunostomy [bariatric surgery (gastric bypass)]

12. insertion of an endoscope and use of ultrasound imaging to visualize the organs of the gastrointestinal tract [endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS)]

13. percutaneous removal of liver tissue followed by microscopic examination [liver biopsy]

14. visual examination (endoscopic) of abdominal viscera through small abdominal incisions [laparoscopy (form of minimally invasive surgery)]

15. new opening of the stomach to the outside of the body for feeding [gastrostomy (G tube)]

16. radioactive imaging of the liver, gallbladder, and intestine [HIDA scan]

instructions.instructions: Match each listed laboratory test or clinical procedure with its description.

questionContent.questionText:
1. TPN [total parenteral nutrition]
2. PUD [peptic ulcer disease]
3. EGD [esophagoduodenoscopy]
4. IBD [inflammatory bowel disease]
5. BE [barium enema]
6. BRBPR [bright red blood per rectum]
7. LFTs [liver function tests]
8. GERD [gastroesophageal reflux disease]
9. HBV [hepatitis B virus]
10. CT [computed tomography]

1. Intravenous injection of nutrition. [total parenteral nutrition]

2. H. pylori causes this condition. [peptic ulcer disease]

3. Endoscopic visualization of the upper gastrointestinal tract. [esophagoduodenoscopy]

4. Includes Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis. [inflammatory bowel disease]

5. This is a lower gastrointestinal series. [barium enema]

6. Hematochezia describes this gastrointestinal symptom. [bright red blood per rectum]

7. Tests such as measurement of ALT, AST, alk phos, and serum bilirubin. [liver function tests]

8. Heartburn is a symptom of this condition. [gastroesophageal reflux disease]

9. This infectious agent causes chronic inflammation of the liver. [hepatitis B virus]

10. X-ray procedure that produces a series of cross-sectional images. [computed tomography]

instructions.instructions: From the dropdown, select the term that best matches the description.

questionContent.questionText:
1. bursting forth (of blood) [-rrhagia/-rrhage]

2. flow, discharge [-rrhea]

3. suture [-rrhaphy]

4. dilation [-ectasis/-ectasia]

5. narrowing (stricture) [-stenosis]

6. vomiting [-emesis]

7. spitting [-ptysis]

8. excision [-ectomy]

9. digestion [-pepsia]

10. eating, swallowing [-phagia]

11. hardening [-sclerosis]

12. stopping, controlling [-stasis]

13. surgical repair [-plasty]

14. opening [-tresia]

15. surgical puncture [-centesis]

16. involuntary contraction [-spasm]

17. new opening [-stomy]

18. incision [-tomy]

instructions.instructions: Give the suffixes for the following terms.

prompt.text: Explain what happens in a fecal transplant and why it is necessary.

readingPart.reading: In a fecal transplant, stool from a healthy donor, is transferred into the colon of a patient/recipient. This is necessary when the patient’s colon contains harmful bacteria, such as C. difficile. After transplant, normal stool bacteria populate the colon of the patient.

questionContent.questionText:
1. When Mrs. Smith began to have diarrhea and crampy abdominal pain, she consulted a [gastroenterologist/urologist/nephrologist] and worried that the cause of her symptoms might be [inflammatory bowel disease/esophageal varices/achalasia].

2. After taking a careful history and performing a thorough physical examination, Dr. Blakemore diagnosed Mr. Bean, a longtime drinker, with [pancreatitis/hemorrhoids/appendicitis]. Mr. Bean had complained of sharp midepigastric pain and a change in bowel habits.

3. Many pregnant women cannot lie flat after eating without experiencing a burning sensation in their chest and throat. The usual cause of this symptom is [gastroesophageal reflux/volvulus/dysentery].

4. Mr. and Mrs. Cho brought their infant son to the clinic after he had several bouts of projectile vomiting. The pediatric surgeon suspected a diagnosis of [pyloric stenosis/inguinal hernia/ascites].

5. Boris had terrible problems with his teeth. He needed not only a periodontist for his [gingivitis/aphthous stomatitis/oral leukoplakia]  but also an [orthodontist/endodontist/oral surgeon] to straighten his teeth.

6. After 6 weeks of radiation therapy to her throat, Betty experienced severe esophageal irritation and inflammation. She complained to her doctor about her resulting [dysphagia//dyspepsia/hematemesis].

7. Steven, age 7 years, is brought to the clinic because of recurrent abdominal pain, occasional constipation and diarrhea, and weight loss. His pediatrician's diagnosis is [celiac disease/lipase deficiency/dysentery] and recommends a [gluten/sugar/fat] -free diet.

8. Chris had been a heavy alcohol drinker all of his adult life. His wife noticed worsening yellow discoloration of the whites of his eyes and skin. After a physical examination and blood tests, his family physician told him his [liver/colon/skin] was diseased. The yellow discoloration was [jaundice/melena/flatus], and his condition was [cirrhosis/steatorrhea/cheilosis].

9. When Carol was working as a phlebotomist, she accidentally cut her finger while drawing a patient's blood. Unfortunately the patient had [hepatitis/pancreatitis/hemoptysis], and HBV was transmitted to Carol. Blood tests and [liver biopsy/gastrointestinal endoscopy/stool culture] confirmed Carol's unfortunate diagnosis. Her doctor told her that her condition was chronic and that she might be a candidate for a [liver/bone marrow/kidney] transplant procedure in the future.

10. Operation Smile is a rescue project that performs surgical repair including [palatoplasty/herniorrhaphy/oral gingivectomy] on children with a congenital cleft in the roof of the mouth.

11. After months of treatment with antibiotics, Anne developed abdominal pain and chronic severe diarrhea. Harmful bacteria (C. difficile) took over her [colon/esophagus/stomach]. To restore normal bacteria to the gut, she received a [fecal transplant/gastric bypass/laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy] .

instructions.instructions: Select the correct term in parentheses to complete each sentence.
